title: Refine “My Dispute – What Should I Do?”: remove free-text chatbot and expand category guidance

requirements.text: Remove the free-text “Describe Your Dispute” chatbot experience from the “My Dispute – What Should I Do?” page, while keeping the category-selection experience as the only guidance workflow.

quotes: remove the free text chatbot, but keep the other part which lets the user select the type of dispute

acceptanceCriteria: On the Dispute Guidance page, users no longer see a “Describe Your Dispute” tab/section or any textarea-based free-text input.
The Dispute Guidance page only presents the dispute category selection workflow (no tabs needed unless additional non-chatbot modes remain).
No build errors from removed imports/references (e.g., DisputeChatbotPanel no longer imported/used).

requirements.text: Expand the guidance content returned for each of the six fixed dispute categories in the category-selection tool to include substantially more specific, dispute-type-tailored information: (a) realistic examples, (b) mediation suitability guidance including when it may not be suitable, (c) clear next steps, (d) practical do’s and don’ts, and (e) legal-information notes written in plain English for India-focused context (informational, not legal advice).

quotes: add some more content for each of the six categories
as much as specific info you can give to suit to the specific types of disputes examples, mediation suitability, next steps, legal info, do’s/don’t

acceptanceCriteria: For each of the six selectable categories (family, business, employment, property/landlord-tenant, consumer, neighborhood), the displayed guidance includes: examples, suitability notes (including caveats), next steps, do’s, don’ts, and legal-information notes.

The content is written in English, uses a professional but approachable tone, avoids heavy legal jargon, and includes a clear informational/not-legal-advice framing consistent with the existing page disclaimer.
The category-selection workflow continues to work end-to-end (select category → fetch guidance → display expanded content) without regressions.

requirements.text: Update backend dispute guidance structures and logic so the category-based guidance API can deliver the expanded guidance fields needed by the frontend, with category-specific tailored content (not the current generic step list).
acceptanceCriteria: The backend’s category-based guidance response includes structured fields sufficient to render: examples, next steps, do’s, don’ts, and legal-information notes (in addition to suitability + reason).
Guidance steps/next-steps are category-specific (not the same list for every category).
No state migration is introduced unless strictly necessary; static category/guidance data changes do not require stable-state migration.

requirements.text: Update the category-selection UI to present the new expanded guidance sections in a clear, scannable layout that remains mobile-friendly and accessible (e.g., headings, lists, and consistent spacing).

quotes: add some more content for each of the six categories

acceptanceCriteria: After selecting a category, the results area renders distinct sections for: Examples, Is mediation suitable?, Recommended next steps, Do’s, Don’ts, and Legal information (wording may vary but meaning must match).
Lists are rendered as semantic lists (ul/ol) where appropriate and are readable on small screens without horizontal scrolling.
The existing disclaimer remains visible on the page and continues to state the tool is not legal advice.

constraints: Frontend must not modify files under frontend/src/components/ui (shadcn components); compose them instead.
Do not edit immutable frontend hook files listed in SYSTEM_CONTEXT (e.g., frontend/src/hooks/useInternetIdentity.ts(x), frontend/src/hooks/useActor.ts, frontend/src/main.tsx).
Backend must remain a single Motoko actor with all logic in backend/main.mo; only add backend/migration.mo if an upgrade of stable state is required.
nonGoals: Do not add new dispute categories beyond the existing fixed set used by the category selector.
Do not introduce any AI/LLM integration or third-party services for dispute analysis.
Do not change Internet Identity authentication behavior (this change is limited to the dispute guidance tool).
Do not add real-time features (e.g., chat, websockets).
